comments.author: bgelens
comments.body:
I had the same issues on my Win10 preview build 14901 (Win10 Post AU). 
I also have VS15 Preview 3 installed.
I went in psbuild.psm1 and updated the Env:VS140COMNTOOLS check to Env:VS150COMNTOOLS. I also had to install Common Tools for Visual C++ 2015 (modify VS install) to make vcvarsall.bat available on my system. Now I'm left with the final issue where CMake doesn't recognize the C++ compiler. Will update when I fix this.

**Update:** VS 15 support for CMake is due October with 3.7.0 release. So will be reverting to Visual Studio 2015. https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/milestones/2

On another note:
The Start-PSBootstrap function install CMake portable if CMake is not already on the system. When it does this, it adds C:\Program Files(x86)\CMake to the Path but this path does not exist with CMake portable. Instead Cmake will be located in C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\bin

comments.author: KarolKaczmarek
comments.body:
@SteveL-MSFT 
For vcvarsall to be present you must have Visual Studio with "Common Tools for Visual C++ 2015" feature installed.
We should also install it in Start-PSBootstrap or at least document it's needed.

@bgelens 
By "Cmake doesn't recognize the C++ compiler" do you mean error like `CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER  not set`?
If so, you may need to add parent of cl.exe (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\bin) to the path.

Also, good point regarding the cmake.portable. Will send PR for that.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body:
I was stung by this as well trying to run Start-PSBuild on a fresh Win10 machine

And it to me this also brings the question of if we are not suggesting to people to have to use the VisualStudio build process then should we remove it being a seemingly hidden requirement (not noted in the building docs) and move to a complete VS free (if possible - not sure as I'm still new to development like this) build process 

If not then we should update the docs to have a simple list of requirements so that anyone could follow along.

Also the Start-PSBuild requires git installed so I think we should also add a check for this in Start-PSBootstrap too.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
.NET Core development does not require Visual Studio but for C++ code, you need a C++ compiler and on Windows you'd typically use Visual Studio to get that.  However, the C++ team announced a stand-alone compiler in a [NuGet pkg](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/vcblog/2016/02/16/try-out-the-latest-c-compiler-toolset-without-waiting-for-the-next-update-of-visual-studio/) back in February.  This is a "preview" of C++ v.next so that might not be ideal.  

Still, I wonder if that could be made to work with the PS Core build - if indeed you'd like to eliminate the VS dependency for the Windows build.  That said, you can get the VS Community Edition for free so requiring VS for the C++ on Windows doesn't seem to onerous to me.
